hedline.hl1: Spano Capital Budget Shows Slight Decrease

abstract.p: Westchester County Exec Andrew Spano proposes 2001 capital budget that includes $12.2 million for road projects and nearly $10 million for county parks improvements, but is $227,000 less than current fiscal budget (M)

block.p: COUNTY Executive Andrew J. Spano has proposed a $60.5 million capital budget for 2001 that includes $12.2 million for road projects and almost $10 million to improve county parks.
The proposal is $227,000 less than the capital budget Mr. Spano submitted for the current fiscal year.
COUNTY Executive Andrew J. Spano has proposed a $60.5 million capital budget for 2001 that includes $12.2 million for road projects and almost $10 million to improve county parks.
The proposal is $227,000 less than the capital budget Mr. Spano submitted for the current fiscal year.

Mr. Spano, a Democrat, also delivered proposed capital budgets for Westchester's sewer, water and refuse disposal districts, which at $35.2 million amount to less than half of 2000's combined district budgets. The current year's budgets included $43.5 million in projects that were required under a consent decree with the state to preserve the environment, Long Island Sound and the Hudson River.

''At first glance, these budgets look very good,'' said Richard G. Wishnie, a Democrat from Briarcliff Manor and chairman of the county legislature's Budget and Appropriations Committee. He said Mr. Spano was planning ahead and avoiding ''spikes in spending'' resulting from unanticapitated expenses.

But Katherine S. Carsky, a Republican member of the legislature's Budget and Appropriations Committee, said, ''I'm glad to see it's reduced, but that should not lull us into a false sense of expectations regarding future spending.''

She observed that the county faced future capital expenses, among them upgrading or replacing the County Jail in Valhalla. Furthermore, she said, the capital expenses budget calls for spending $2.5 million to construct a sewer system to serve the Quarry Heights section of North Castle. ''Other communities may ask for the same in the future.''
The capital budget, which will be financed by issuing bonds, includes the following:
*Airport: $4.72 million for new projects, including $500,000 toward creation of a buffer around the Kensico Reservoir.
*Open Space and the Environment: $5 million for open space acquisition.
*Affordable Housing: $19.6 million to acquire land for new homes.

*Buildings and Miscellaneous: $6 million to modernize Social Services district offices in White Plains and Peekskill; $4.5 million to upgrade county office space, and $1.5 million to replace air-conditioning equipment.
*Parkways, Roads and Bridges: $12.2 million for 14 projects.

*Recreation: $9.8 million to improve parks, including modernizing Willson's Woods Pool in Mount Vernon and construction of an aquatic playground at the Sprain Ridge Pool in Yonkers; an additional soccer field at V. E. Macy Park in Greenburgh; and $1.85 million for new rides for Playland Amusement Park.
*Transportation: $9.52 million for replacement vehicles and improvements to the Yonkers Bus Garage.
